subject: RE: [junit] Passing parameters to methods
msgSnippet: ... Robert Watkins ... It s not a big deal but imagine a class that has ten test methods and each of them needs a different parameter.  Are you going to pass
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Robert Watkins

> Well, personally, I've got no problem with using Method
> Objects, so the idea of passing parameters in as constructors
> isn't a big deal.

It's not a big deal but imagine a class that has ten test methods and each
of them needs a different parameter. Are you going to pass all these
parameters in the constructor, store them in a separate field and then have
each method use the particular field they need?

> The idea that I have to have tests run in a particular
> order to get repeatability strikes me as odd as well

Why would you need to do that? We are just talking about being able to pass
parameters to test methods. The order in which these methods are invoked is
irrelevant... right?

> > Yes, with @Factory.
>
> Thanks...

By the way, I believe that both TestNG (@Factory) and JUnit (suite()) made a
mistake when implementing this concept of a factory: it should be an
interface.

Both @Factory and suite() suffer from the "too much magic" problem: no type
checking, signatures verified at runtime (and easily misspelled), etc...

Maybe something like:

public interface ITestFactory {
public Object[] suite();
}

> Have you thought about an option like this?
>
> @ParameterList({ "oneName" }, {"anotherName"}, {"aThirdName"})
> @Test public void testSingleString(String firstName) { ...
> }

You mean defining the various values in the source itself?

No, I hadn't thought about it, but it's an intriguing idea. My first
reaction is that it would force me to recompile my source file whenever I
want to change or add a parameter, but I can see how a JUnit user wouldn't
mind that :-)

I'll forward this idea to the mailing-list, see what people think of it.

> The vast majority of times I want a parameterised test, I
> don't really want a _lot_ of parameters, but I'm not sure I'd
> want to muck around with defining the parameters in the XML
> either;

Fair enough, I'm open to hearing suggestions, but I really think that you
need a way to be able to invoke the same test class with different values
for parameters. How would you like to do that?

> I can tell you outright that the major reason I don't
> even want to think about converting a serious project to
> TestNG is that the XML file is a turn off.

The XML file is optional and mainly here to make it easy to drive TestNG
with tools (the Eclipse and IDEA plug-in use it a lot) or to provide
repeatability (testng-failed.xml, or just email a certain test suite to a
coworker).

Most users simply invoke TestNG from ant or from the command line and they
never write a single line of XML.

--
Cedric
